Morgan was a trailblazer, an inventor, a businessman, and a community leader. His work has saved countless lives.  #BlackHistoryMonth https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/black-inventor-garrett-morgan-saved-countless-lives-with-gas-mask-and-improved-traffic-lights/

The first traffic light, a two-light ‚Äústop/go‚Äù signal had been developed in London. But Morgan improved on the design, adding the third signal ‚Äì yellow ‚Äì to the light to reduce traffic congestion patterns and accidents. Today, it‚Äôs everywhere. https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/garrett-morgan-patents-three-position-traffic-signal

Morgan personally risked his life to help save the trapped men, rescuing eight. National newspapers reported on the rescue, but neglected to mention his role. He wrote to the mayor, ‚ÄúI am not a well-educated man; however, I have a Ph.D. from the school of hard knocks.‚Äù

He became known as ‚Äúthe inventor of Harlem Avenue,‚Äù where he lived. In 1916, a group of miners were buried in a tunnel collapse under Lake Erie. The Cleveland Police called Morgan, who rushed ‚Äì still in his pajamas ‚Äì with masks and volunteers down to the tunnel.

His love of creating pushed him to experiment, leading to his prototype of a breathing device which would serve as the early blueprint of the gas masks used in WWI. It sold poorly, until he hired a white man to pretend to be the inventor in a demonstration. Then it took off.

Morgan started as a sewing machine repairmen. The process of taking apart and rebuilding the machines fascinated him, and he tinkered with how to improve their production quality. He started his first business with his wife, and became a community leader in Cleveland.

Garrett Morgan was a Black inventor and businessman. He became particularly known for safety products, including the modern day three-color American traffic light and an early gas mask, but also had a line of beauty products for Black hair. #BlackHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FLpN_g3XwAEVfdF.jpg
